title: RNN-Transducer-based Losses for Speech Recognition on Noisy Targets
author: Vladimir Bataev (University of London)
relevance_why: The paper directly addresses improvements in automatic speech recognition (ASR) using RNN-Transducer systems, which is closely related to Dr. Liu's research on audio processing and speech enhancement. The exploration of loss modifications for training ASR models on noisy data has significant implications for developing robust audio models.
background: Improving automatic speech recognition systems by training on datasets with noisy and unreliable transcripts to achieve better speech recognition performance.
contribution: This paper introduces novel loss modifications for RNN-Transducer systems to enhance robustness against noisy transcripts, achieving improved performance on speech recognition tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily focused on clean and well-transcribed data, which limits the applicability of ASR in real-world scenarios where transcripts are often noisy or erroneous.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon existing ASR systems by effectively employing loss modifications that specifically target various types of transcription errors, such as deletions, insertions, and substitutions, enhancing alignment and prediction accuracy.

key_innovation: Proposes a framework for applying various loss modifications based on weighted finite state transducers (WFSTs) to optimize RNN-Transducer performance under noisy conditions, broadening the applicability of ASR systems.
real_world_impact: By enabling ASR systems to effectively deal with noisy or partially incorrect training data, this research could significantly improve speech recognition technology in various practical applications, such as call centers or personal assistants where noise is a common issue.
limitations: No major limitations are explicitly mentioned by the author.

new_terms.RNN-Transducer: **Recurrent Neural Network Transducer (RNN-T)** is an end-to-end speech recognition architecture that combines a neural network encoder, a prediction network, and a joint network for generating transcriptions from audio signals.
new_terms.weighted finite state transducer (WFST): **Weighted Finite State Transducer (WFST)** is a mathematical representation used for managing and processing sequences of data, like speech or text, with an emphasis on capturing various alignments and transformations.
